contribution_type: Concept notes should cover a project that will only provide service in Pakistan.  PRM’s mandate is to provide protection, assistance, and sustainable solutions for refugees and victims of conflict; therefore, PRM will prioritize funding projects that include at least 50 percent of Proof of Registration (POR) cardholding refugees.  Projects may also include undocumented Afghans and Afghans of other status given appropriate coordination with UNHCR.  PRM encourages coordination with UNHCR to ensure projects complement the Afghanistan Situation Regional Refugee Response Plan.

DRL will award one cooperative agreement to a consortium of implementing partners to expand space for freedom of association and promote internationally recognized labor rights in Latin America and the Caribbean.  The consortium will strengthen workers’ ability to pursue evidence-based strategic advocacy for decent rights at work and claim their legal rights and protections in line with international standards.  The proposal should focus primarily on the consortium design, management structure and programmatic approach as well as the role and unique capability of each the proposed consortium partners.  Detailed country-specific workplans will be developed in coordination with DRL.

DRL’s programmatic emphasis advances the U.S. government policy to promote human rights in the Western Hemisphere as stated in the March 2021 Interim National Security Strategic Guidance.  Specifically, DRL programs in Cuba aim to strengthen the capabilities of on-island, independent civil society to advance the human rights and fundamental freedoms of all individuals in Cuba, and to overcome the limitations imposed by the Cuban government on the exercise of these civil, political, labor, and religious rights.  DRL strives to ensure its projects also advance principles of non-discrimination with respect to race, religion, gender, disability, sexual orientation, gender identity, and other individual characteristics.

DRL expects this approach to include a formative evaluation that assesses the progress of the piloted networking activities during the period of performance. This evaluation will be designed in collaboration with DRL upon award, but should be assumed to include regular qualitative data collection, analysis, and adaptation based on feedback from program stakeholders.

DRL’s goal is that youth (age 15-25) become meaningful contributors to, as well as more discerning consumers of, media.  Program objectives are to (1) ensure that youth citizen journalists/content creators develop more professional and ethical journalistic practices and (2) increase their ability to identify and analyze fact-based, high-quality news and information.  Desired outcomes of this program include: (1) youth citizen journalists/content creators expand their contributions to the free flow of information while practicing ethical journalism, and launch initiatives to address disinformation; and (2) civil society organizations (CSOs) provide platforms for youth to both amplify their work while highlighting relevant issues for young people and identify sources of high-quality news and information.  Activities could include, but are not limited to, training youth in citizen journalism skills and ethical online content creation; strengthening the capacity of CSOs to work with youth citizen journalists and highlight key issues in the country from a youth perspective; and developing media initiatives such as fact-checking websites, youth debates, or infotainment/news programs that debunk false narratives and/or create fact-based media content to address disinformation.  Proposals should demonstrate the ability to coordinate closely with other actors and programs in the country and ensure that activities do not duplicate existing efforts.
DRL WHA Program Learning Series - United States Department of State
DRL Burma Conflict-Related Sexual Violence (CRSV) Documentation Project - United States Department of State

DRL’s goal is to champion a strong independent media sector in the region that is resistant to powerful interests seeking to manipulate, isolate, or control the press.  In support of this goal, DRL seeks proposals that enable media actors to: 1) network within their countries and across the region, where appropriate; 2) improve cross-border content production and contextualizing of national stories into regional perspectives and better connect media and audiences across target countries; and 3) produce and disseminate high-quality and credible content across platforms that address issues of importance in their local communities and counter disinformation.  Proposals may also include activities that support the development of new and/or improved online and mobile platforms that offer multimedia features enabling greater interactivity and connectivity with audiences locally and across countries.  Networks may encourage participating outlets to exchange best practices regarding effective media management, increasing viewership, and improving content to meet viewers’ needs.  Program outcomes should result in outlets becoming trusted sources of information, establishing strong links to the communities they serve, enhancing their market share in the marketplace of ideas, and enhancing cross-border cooperation and high-quality content sharing among independent media in the region.

DRL’s goal is to increase civic and political participation of Roma, as well as other ethnic minorities, in Central Europe.  DRL requests proposals that seek to increase the capacity of Roma and other ethnic minority leaders to advocate for and effectuate their inclusion and to increase their representation in political parties.  Activities could include: training Roma and other minority civic leaders and civil society organizations (CSOs) to effectively engage in political advocacy, and to participate in decision-making and political processes; providing opportunities for participants to network with other minority leaders both within their own countries and through regional civil society networks; and targeting training for civic leaders and CSOs on advocacy skills, political engagement, legal rights and enforcement, organizational management, community organizing, and communication skills. Countries that are eligible for participation include Bulgaria, Czech Republic, Hungary, Romania, and Slovakia.  Proposals must include a minimum of three countries.

DRL requests proposals for a $1,000,000 project to strengthen internationally recognized labor rights for workers in Indonesia’s mining industries by increasing workers’ knowledge of their rights to safety and health at work and their ability to organize to advance those rights.  Projects must identify two or more specific mining sectors of focus and include minerals for which significant growth in demand and production is anticipated.

DRL’s goal is that institutions and authorities uphold the rule of law, protect and advance fundamental freedoms, and adopt an inclusive and rights-based approach to governance.  DRL seeks proposals that address the following program objective: Moldovan civil society contributes to the effectiveness of governing institutions, such that they are more resilient, accessible, transparent, participatory, and responsive.  Intended outcomes should include a coalition (formal or informal) of Moldovan organizations representing all populations, including Roma, LGBTQI+ persons, women, rural communities, Jewish communities, and persons with disabilities.  This coalition should articulate and advocate for the needs of these groups at all levels on topics such as access to justice, selective justice, and corruption as it impacts their local communities; build a community of trust and partnership that includes members of the coalition, representatives from the judicial sector, local government entities, and relevant rule of law organizations that can discuss justice sector reform priorities and challenges; and engage in justice sector monitoring and oversight by leveraging existing mechanisms, as appropriate.

DRL’s goal is that ​governments implement tangible democratic reforms, including reforms to promote government transparency.  DRL requests proposals that will further the program goal ​of exposing corruption at local government levels in Montenegro and implementing measures to prevent future corruption.  Program objectives are for civil society and media to report on and/or counter corruption in local or regional executive and legislative bodies, especially in social spheres, such as environmental concerns, education, and health care; support the engagement of citizens and journalists to monitor those sectors and activities where corruption frequently occurs; report the results to authorities, media, and the wider public, including appropriate international bodies; and monitor government responses and/or accountability measures.  The program may include support for constructive engagement between civil society, the private sector, and government stakeholders to strengthen anti-corruption mechanisms, facilitate the implementation of best practices in countering corruption, and urge action in specific cases (if appropriate and feasible).  Program outcomes should include identification of corrupt practices; reporting of corrupt practices to relevant government entities; and increased public awareness of corruption.

DRL’s goal is to promote justice and accountability for gross human rights violations in Libya. DRL’s objectives are to advocate for the rights of missing and disappeared persons and support access to justice and services for their families; to strengthen civil society engagement in efforts to promote truth, justice and accountability for missing persons; and to strengthen the ability of Libyan authorities to address the mass graves issue in close coordination with civil society, family associations, and in accordance with international standards.

DRL’s goal is the enhanced  participation and protection of women civil society activists, journalists, and peacebuilders in countries where women are playing a central role in conflict prevention and other transitional processes.  DRL’s objectives are to advance women’s participation and leadership in public life, particularly as it relates to conflict prevention, transitional processes, and COVID-19 response efforts; strengthen protection and support mechanisms for women civil society activists, journalists, and peacebuilders; and improve public awareness of the unique roles, risks, and challenges that these women face in carrying out their work.

DRL anticipates awarding either a grant or cooperative agreement depending on the needs and risk factors of the program.  The final determination on award mechanism will be made by the Grants Officer.  The distinction between grants and cooperative agreements revolves around the existence of “substantial involvement.”  Cooperative agreements require greater Federal government participation in the project.  If a cooperative agreement is awarded, DRL will undertake reasonable and programmatically necessary substantial involvement.  Examples of substantial involvement can include, but are not limited to:
